Trait description: The extent of damage caused by brown planthopper (Nilparvata lugens). Symptoms: Partial to pronounced yellowing and increasing severity of stunting. Extreme signs are wilting to death of plants. Infested areas in the field may be patchy
Method description: Observe the damage on the plants caused by brown planthopper. For a field test, use an augmented experimental design with a susceptible check replicated at intervals across the whole trial. The test is considered a valid test for resistance if the hopper population is uniformly distributed at a high level across the screening box, as indicated by hopper counts on the susceptible check. A minimum of the following hopper density on susceptible check is necessary: a. 10 hoppers/hill at 10-15 days after transplanting, b. 25 hoppers / hiII at maximum tillering, c. 100 hoppers/hill at early booting stage
Category 2: 1= slight yellowing of a few plants
Category 3: 3= Leaves partially yellow but with no hopperburn
Category 4: 5= Leaves with pronounced yellowing and some stunting or wilting and 10-25% of plants with hopperburn, remaining plants severely stunted
Category 5: 7= More than half the plants wilting or with hopperburn, remaining plants severely stunted

Trait description: This is a compound trait used for F1 hybrids combining the proportion of fertile spikelets  at maturity with the proportion of fertile pollen at anthesis
Method description: Step 1 (pollen fertility: see pollen sterility score): Collect pollen from at least ten florets at anthesis, fix in 70% alcohol. Place 2-3 anthers from each of five florets on a glass slide, and squeeze the pollen out in a drop of 1% iodine potassium iodide (I2-KI) solution with a spear-shaped needle. Using a microscope at magnification 10x10, count fertile and sterile grains in at least three microscopic fields, calculate the percentage that are fertile, and score. Step 2 (spikelet fertility): count the number of filled grains andtotal spikelets per panicle and convert into percentage fertile. Score the combination of pollen fertility with spikelet fertility
Category 1: 1= pollen and spikelets both 90% fertile or above
Category 2: 2= pollen 80-89% fertile, spikelets 90% fertile or above
Category 3: 3= pollen 90% fertile or above, spikelets 75-89% fertile

Trait description: Describes the consistency of a rice gel formed by grinding, chemically treating, boiling, and cooling a sample of grains. This measures the tendency of cooked rice to harden on cooling, a function of carbohydrate composition
Method description: Place 0.1g ground rice in a test tube with thymol blue (0.025% in ethanol, 0.2 ml) and KOH (0.2N, 2 ml). Shake the tube to mix contents, boil (8 min), rest (5 min) and then place in an ice-bath (15 min). Lay cooled tubes flat on graph paper for 1 hour, and then measure the distance that the gel travels . Included standards, as the age of the rice, degree of milling and operator skill affect reproducibility: IR48 (8590 mm), IR32 (72-75 mm) and IR42 (30-32 mm).

Trait description: The degree of male (pollen) sterility
Method description: Collect pollen from at least ten florets at anthesis, fix in 70% alcohol. Place 2-3 anthers from each of five florets on a glass slide, and squeeze the pollen out in a drop of 1% iodine potassium iodide (I2-KI) solution with a spear-shaped needle. Fertile pollen grains will be round and well stained, sterile pollen grains will be unstained or partially stained, and withered or round. Using a microscope at magnification 10x10, count fertile and sterile grains in at least three microscopic fields, calculate the proportion that are sterile

Trait synonyms: rice ragged stunt disease, ragged stunt

Method description: Score RaggedStuntSev_Est_0to9 5 weeks after inoculation in the greenhouse, and calculate Disease Index DI= (20xN3 + 40xN5 + 70xN7 + 100xN9)/NT, where N3-N9 are the number of plants with score 3-9 and NT is total number of plants scored  .

Trait synonyms: rice ragged stunt disease, ragged stunt

Method description: Estimate the type and severity of symptoms
Category 2: 3= 0-10% height reduction, no ragged/twisted leaf, very few veins slightly swollen usually on leaf collar
Category 3: 5= 0-10% height reduction, 1-2 leaves ragged/twisted, few veins swollen on leaf collar
Category 4: 7= 11-30% height reduction, 3-4leaves ragged/twisted, more vein swelling on leaf collar and some on leafblades and leaf sheaths
Category 5: 9= More than 30% height reduction, most leaves ragged/twisted, vein swellingcommon on leaf sheaths and leaf blades

Trait description: The extent of damage caused by rats. Symptoms: the tiller is cut at a 45 degrees angle. Damage is typically heavier in the center of a crop (stadium effect). A tiller cut through by a rodent is likely to regrow, if this is after maximum tillering then the regrown tiller is unlikely to produce panicles prior to harvest. Often the regrown, but non productive, tillers are not scored as rodent damage.
Method description: Estimate the proportion of plants that are damaged by rats

Trait description: Describes the presence of rhizomes, stolons and/or tubers in the mature plant
Method description: Wild species: observe the presence of rhizomes, stolons and/or tubers around the base of a potted plant when it is ready for harvest
Category 4: 4= Vegetative crown, stolon and weak rhizomes

Trait description: The extent of plant damage caused by rice bug (Leptocorisa oratorisa).
Method description: Observe the proportion of injured grains per panicle caused by rice bug

Trait description: The extent of damage caused by rice delphacid (Sogatodes oryzicola (Tagosodes orizicolus)). Symptoms: partial to pronounced yellowing and increasing severity of stunting. Extreme signs are wilting and death of plants. Infested areas in the field may be patchy.
Method description: Sow plants in a greenhouse with a uniform high population of green leafhopper, and observe the damage on seedlings
Category 4: 5= Pronounced yellowing of leaves and stunting, fewer than 50% of plants dead
Category 5: 7= Strong yellowing of leaves and pronounced stunting, more than 50% of plants dead

Trait description: The extent of damage caused by rice delphacid (Sogatodes oryzicola (Tagosodes orizicolus)). Symptoms: partial to pronounced yellowing and increasing severity of stunting. Extreme signs are wilting and death of plants. Infested areas in the field may be patchy.
Method description: Observe the damages on plants caused by rice delphacid. For a field test, use an augmented experimental design with a susceptible check replicated at intervals across the whole trial. The test is considered a valid test for resistance if the hopper population is uniformly distributed at a high level across the screening box, as indicated by hopper counts on the susceptible check. A minimum of the following hopper density on susceptible check is necessary: a. 10 hoppers/hill at 10-15 days after transplanting, b. 25 hoppers / hiII at maximum tillering, c. 100 hoppers/hill at early booting stage
Category 4: 5= Pronounced yellowing of leaves and stunting, fewer than 50% of plants dead
Category 5: 7= Strong yellowing of leaves and pronounced stunting, more than 50% of plants dead

Method description: Estimate the stunting and discoloration
Category 2: 3= 1-10% height reduction, no distinct yellow to yellow orange leaf discoloration
Category 3: 5= 11-30% height reduction, no distinct yellow to yellow orange leaf discoloration
Category 4: 7= 31-50% height reduction, with distinct yellow to yellow orange leaf discoloration
Category 5: 9= More than 50% height reduction, with distinct yellow to yellow orange discoloration

Trait synonyms: tungro, tungo disease, rice tungro virus

Method description: Grow plants in a greenhouse. Inoculate seedlings. Score RTungroSev_Est_0to9 after 4 weeks, and calculate Disease Index DI= (20xN3 + 40xN5 + 70xN7 + 100xN9)/NT, where N3-N9 are the number of plants with score 3-9 and NT is total number of plants scored

Category 3: 3= 2 or more leaves/hill but less than 1/3 of leaves injured
Category 5: 7= More than 1/2 of the leaves injured with no broken leaves
Category 6: 9= More than 1/2 of the injured with some broken leaves

The test is considered a valid test for resistance if the susceptible check has more than 20% of tillers with deadheart
